Award.AwardTitle: Belmont Forum-G8 Initiative Collaborative Research: Southern Africa's Hydro-Economy and Water Security: SAHEWS
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support to U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 13-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum and the G8 countries Heads of Research Councils. The Belmont Forum is a high level group of the world?s major and emerging funders of global environmental change research and international science councils. It aims to accelerate delivery of the international environmental research most urgently needed to remove critical barriers to sustainability by aligning and mobilizing international resources. The G8 Heads of Research Councils developed a funding framework to support multilateral research projects that address global challenges in ways that are beyond the capacity of national or bilateral activities. Each partner country provides funding for their researchers within a consortium to alleviate the need for funds to cross international borders. This approach facilitates effective leveraging of national resources to support excellent research on topics of global relevance best tackled through a multinational approach, recognizing that global challenges need global solutions.

Working together in an inaugural call of the International Opportunities Fund, the Belmont Forum and G8HORCs have provided support for research projects that seek to deliver knowledge needed for action to mitigate and adapt to detrimental environmental change and extreme hazardous events that relate to either Freshwater Security or Coastal Vulnerability. This award provides support for the U.S. researchers to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., policy makers, regulators, NGOs, communities and industry).

This award supports research activities that will address important knowledge gaps in water supply, demand and sharing, and in the application of research to the effective management of freshwater security in Southern Africa. Numerous challenges including population growth, drought-induced food shortages, increasing energy demands and a variable climate interact to make Southern Africa especially sensitive to freshwater security threats. Adding to these challenges is a lack of institutional and policy instruments for equitable and sustainable management of supply and demand in the broader hydro-economy. This project will integrate an understanding of short to medium term hydro-meteorological variability and its socioeconomic consequences to develop approaches for improved regional water resources management. Researchers will develop an improved understanding of hydro-meteorological variability and human-environmental interactions to characterize how this variability affects the regional hydro-economy. This will be achieved through careful case study and co-designed research and facilitated high level knowledge exchange. This project will contribute an improved understanding of the global climate-water-food-energy nexus to support decision making and equitable and sustainable freshwater management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Belmont Forum-G8 Collaborative Research "SAHEWS - Southern Africa's Hydro-economy and Water Security," which was led by the University of East Anglia (UK) with partners Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), South Africa, and the US NSF-supported partner the International Food Policy Research Institute focus on four objectives: 1) Improve understanding of hydro-meteorological variability and seasonal forecast reliability across Southern Africa; 2) Improve understanding and characterization of Southern Africa's hydro-economy and large-scale drivers of freshwater variability; 3) Enhance knowledge use by decision-makers in the region through case study collaborations following a demand-led research co-design process; and 4) Facilitie high level knowledge exchange through a range of carefully targeted outputs.

A review paper pulished on Nature Climate Change under this project identified high physical and socioeconomic exposure to climate across regions and in sectors crucial to the economy. Spatial interdependence is also high with climate anomolies spanning transboundary river basins and aquifers. Adverse impacts from climate variability and change on national and regional economies is expected to grow as a result of both increased temperature and projected declines in precipitation levels, advesely affecting agricultural production and regional economic growth. The paper identifies three instruments to strengthen the region in the face of growing water variability: 1) the Southern African Development Community (SADC); 2) the Southern African Power Pool; and 3) trade across the region and from other regions with the Southern African region.

A fourth instrument identified to address growing water variability is the better use of seasonal forecasts to inform agricultural production. A project paper by Rodrigues et al. (2016) valued the economic returns to improved seasonal forecasting systems as the systems are expensive to establish and maintain and are seldom used (see also the following set of results). The authors used a computable general equilibrium model and process-based crop models to estimate the potential economy-wide value of national seasonal forecast systems in Kenya, Malawi, Mozambique, Tanzania and Zambia. They find that timely and accurate forecasts adopted by all farmers could generate average regional income gains of US$113 million per year. Gains are much higher during extreme climate events and are generally pro-poor. The forecast value falls when forecast skill and farm coverage decline. National economic and trading structures, including the importance of agricultural exports are found to be major determinants of forecast value.

The paper on assessing the impact of water variability on water and food security and solutions to addressing this growing challenge found the following: Alleviating economic water scarcity through investment in water infrastructure can reduce irrigation water shortages, enhance water supply reliability, increase food production, and reduce international market prices of food commodities. The degree that water infrastructure investment relieves water scarcity varies by hydrological year type. In extremely dry years, the water supply augmentation effects of infrastructure may become limited by physical water scarcity. Compared with the average crop yield improvement with water infrastructure investment, crop yield increase effects are generally more apparent in drought years. Impacts of alternative investment options vary between irrigation water supply reliability outcomes and crop yield and production outcomes because water allocation among crops follows the principle of farm income maximization. The effectiveness of water infrastructure investment differs across locations. Factors that affects such effectiveness include economic development status, water resources endowment, hydro climatic characteristics and prospects of demographic and economic growth. Although the infrastructure scenario in this paper assumes that in a world without economic water scarcity reservoir storage and the capacity to abstract surface water in southern Africa do not limit water supply, it is unlikely that the maximum level of infrastructure will actually be implemented.

To complement scientific analyses and help ensure impact, we worked with a local NGO in South Africa to assess the reasons for limited adoption of seasonal forecast information in South Africa. Project partners in South Africa and the UK also worked directly with South African government agencies on enhanced seasonal forecast information to address first the wrong El Nino forecast in 2014/15, followed by the actual El Nino event 2015/16. The project also participated in a wide range of national, regional and global events, including various conferences in South Africa on seasonal forecasting, a meeting in Mozambique organized by the Ministry of Agriculture, IFPRI and Michigan State University where SAHEWS results were presented, a session at Africa Water Week in July 2016, an organized session and a presentation at Stockholm World Water Week and various presentations at annual AGU meetings. SAHEWs project partners gave many additional presentations in Europe and Africa, which are listed in the section below.
